text: they're playing a constructive role in a
community where they were once despised
this is big different with one half
years ago we now have respect now for us
the chronic alcoholics are offered an
incentive five cans of free beer and 10
euros a day for five hours work it's
less than the Netherlands minimum wage
bus offers an opportunity that they
couldn't find elsewhere this peaceful
oasis was once shattered by stabbings
muggings families and especially women
were intimidated now more than 20 of the
regulars have been convinced to abandon
their Park life this might sound like a
bizarre concept giving alcohol to
alcoholics but it's a typically Dutch
pragmatic approach to dealing with the
problem it's based on a strategy of harm
reduction and it's one that they say is
working they are the rainbow foundation
a partly state-funded group that runs
this pioneering project it's better for
the neighborhood they do something back
for the society they're cleaning the
streets they have more structure and
they drink less and I think it's all
you're win-win situation
but in a city where prostitution is
legal and cannabis decriminalized some
conservatives feel free beer for
alcoholics is taking this liberal
approach too far
it might not appeal to everyone's taste
but it's been Fred's salvation he became
alcohol dependence after the death of
his wife this is now his life and uglies
I do I tried you took my I cannot I
cannot stop none of these guys intend to
get clean but changing their habits and
channeling their energy does appear to
be having a positive impact on the
streets Anna hooligan BBC news in
Amsterdam
